properties.title: "Big Mouth endures": The Great Burger War stops in at Big Mouth
properties.desc: The Burger Next Door. Delivers a solid burger in a pinch if you live in the Mission and don’t want to pay a premium.
properties.byline: by Mark Rabine and Julian Mark

properties.title: Burger Wars goes to Monk's Kettle
properties.desc: The Kettle may be known for its extravagant number of beers, but many neighborhood eaters appreciate its unspectacular, consistently satisfying food.
properties.byline: by Mark Rabine and Julian Mark

properties.title: Burger Wars goes to Super Duper
properties.desc: Comparing the Super to True Laurel’s patty melt is like comparing a battleship to a sailboat.
properties.byline: by Mark Rabine and Julian Mark

properties.title: Burger Wars visits Jay's Cheesesteak
properties.desc: Not only do you get to choose cooking style, but you get to choose among seven cheeses, eight variations of fries, seven condiments, eleven extra options and nine sauces.
properties.byline: by Mark Rabine and Julian Mark

properties.title: Burger Wars visits Plain Jane
properties.desc: The first bite brought notes of char, quality beef, sweetness from the caramelized onion and tang from the cheddar. The bun, as is only natural, played the perfect supporting role.
properties.byline: by Julian Mark and Mark Rabine

properties.title: Burger Wars visits True Laurel
properties.desc: The sandwich — if you could call it that — was puny, wafer-thin, and dwarfed by the plate it came on.
properties.byline: by Julian Mark and Mark Rabine

properties.title: Burger Wars visits Zeitgeist
properties.desc: The patty was on the thin side, barely a quarter pound, and submitted without protest to the bun’s thick dominance.
properties.byline: by Mark Rabine and Julian Mark

properties.title: The Burger War goes to Bender's
properties.address: Bender's Bar & Grill, 806 S Van Ness Ave, 94110
properties.desc: They serve the burgers your dad made — or always wanted to make: juicy and charred, unabashedly sloppy and improvised-looking, the kind of cholesterol bomb that prompts the side-eye from the heart doctor.
properties.byline: by Julian Mark

properties.title: The Burger War goes to Son's Addition
properties.desc: Why are the French never content to let the food speak for itself without all the fuss and fluff of the ancien regime?
properties.byline: by Mark Rabine and Julian Mark

properties.title: The Burger War goes to World of Noodles
properties.desc: A double cheeseburger for less than five dollars? At a noodle spot, no less? Who wouldn’t try that?
properties.byline: by Julian Mark and Mark Rabine

properties.title: The Burger Wars visits Beep's Burgers
properties.desc: It features all the best attributes of the burgers we consider the best: the dankness of Super Duper, the All-American delight of In-N-Out, and the simplicity of Shake Shack. But it’s home-grown here in San Francisco, and there’s only one.
properties.byline: by Julian Mark and Mark Rabine

properties.title: The Great Burger War begins at Whiz Burgers
properties.address: Whiz Burgers, 700 S Van Ness Ave, 94110
properties.desc: I won’t mince words or beef or whatever: The burger at Whiz Burgers wasn’t … good. But it didn’t cross the threshold of bad, either.
properties.byline: by Julian Mark and Mark Rabine

properties.title: The Great Burger War goes to ABV
properties.desc: No matter how much I tried, I couldn’t write around the one thing in this world with which to compare the sensation of eating the burger at ABV: Orgasm.
properties.byline: by Julian Mark and Mark Rabine

properties.title: The Great Burger War goes to Double Decker
properties.desc: If not a home run, Double Decker hit a solid double. Maybe a triple. An encouraging sign for the upcoming season.
properties.byline: by Mark Rabine and Julian Mark

properties.title: The Great Burger War goes to Jake's Steaks
properties.desc: The burger provided me with plenty to chew on and it filled me up. It was reliable, considerate — but bland, uninspiring. A token menu item in the end.
properties.byline: by Julian Mark and Mark Rabine

properties.title: The Great Burger War goes to Popsons
properties.desc: All told, the cheeseburger with seasoned fries alone (plus tax, tip, service and delivery fees), cost $16.55. And, really, the whole experience was so predictably — horrifyingly — American.
properties.byline: by Julian Mark and Mark Rabine

properties.title: The Great Burger War goes to the Mission Bowling Club
properties.desc: This burger, the Mission Burger at Mission Bowling Club, is out of this world.
properties.byline: by Julian Mark and Mark Rabine

properties.title: The Great Burger War goes to The Pork Store
properties.desc: We didn’t define the characteristics and parameters of a “burger” when we began, arrogantly assuming there was a single, universal, meaning to the term. Not true.
properties.byline: by Mark Rabine and Julian Mark

properties.title: The Great Burger War goes to the Red Cafe
properties.desc: The burger at The Red Cafe is like every item at the Red Cafe: You may ask yourself after finishing a meal there: Did it really need to be that good?
properties.byline: by Julian Mark and Mark Rabine

properties.title: The Great Burger War goes to Trick Dog's 'Quik Dog'
properties.address: Quik Dog by Trick Dog, 3010 20th St, 94110
properties.desc: The only possible downside to these fries is their arrogance. They know they’re special: so damn good and so many of them, they trample over the “world famous” burger.
properties.byline: by Mark Rabine

properties.title: The Great Burger War goes to WesBurger
properties.desc: I respect myself and try to live without regrets. This week, after ordering from WesBurger not once, but twice, I’m full of regret. And shame. Perhaps even some anger.
properties.byline: by Julian Mark

properties.title: The Great Burger War stops at West of Pecos
properties.desc: Though unremarkable, the bun bravely stood up to the cheese dip and sauce throughout the meal. Not so much the droopy fries that seemed bored and tired by the time I got them home.
properties.byline: by Julian Mark

properties.title: The Great Burger War tries Curio
properties.desc: Do you know what happens when you consume something that purports to be the Holy Grail and isn’t?
properties.byline: by Julian Mark and Mark Rabine
